translated: Having ascertained that the sun and moon exist in the individual body just as in the universe, the attainment of the union with the stars is said to occur by seeing their unity with the stars. As a non-yogin sees the sun and moon in the universe with the stars aided by the mind, so the yogin should look at the sun and moon shining in the sky of his head with the stars aided by the mind. The meaning is that seeing forms depends on the eyes, so what is the use of the mind? To this he says that. When the mind is engaged elsewhere, the eye etc. do not have the power to grasp forms etc. This is because there is no seeing when the mind is elsewhere, and no hearing when the mind is elsewhere, as stated in the Vedas. Since it is so, therefore.

translated: That Tāraka is of two kinds: embodied Tāraka and disembodied Tāraka. That which ends with the senses is embodied. That which is beyond the eyebrows is disembodied. In all discrimination of internal objects, practice connected with the mind is desired. By the two Tāraka, due to the vision of the existent located above, the Brahman which is the nature of existence, consciousness, and bliss, is connected with the internal eye along with the mind. Therefore, it is established that Brahman is made of white light. That Brahman becomes knowable by the internal vision of the eye aided by the mind. Thus, the embodied Tāraka also. By the eye connected with the mind alone, the subtle body etc. become knowable. Because the purpose of grasping form depends on the mind and eye, and because the effect of grasping form arises only through the non-conjunction of the internal and external self, mind, and eye. Therefore, the internal vision connected with the mind becomes the light of the Tāraka.

translated: The answer to the question What is to be meditated upon? is given by the word that (tat). The discrimination of internal objects is dependent on the mind and eyes, like the discrimination of external objects. Therefore, it is said everywhere (sarvatra). Because of seeing beings above that (tat ūrdhva-sattva-darśanāt). Because of seeing the mark of the upper tārā, which shines in the middle of the eyebrows (bhru-madhya-ūrdhva-vilasita-uttaratārā-lakṣya-darśanāt). By whom is this to be seen? By one united with the mind (manaḥ-yuktena). Brahman alone is the mark of the upper tārā. This is to be meditated upon (anu-saṃ-dhātavyam). Since it is so, therefore (tasmāt). Although the shining white light located in the middle of the eyebrows and so on is imagined by the mind, Brahman, being all-pervading, exists there also. Therefore, the mind dissolves into that Brahman with the firmness of conviction (abhimati-dṛḍhimnā). When the mind dissolves there, the imagination that requires an imaginer being absent, Brahman alone, which is free from conceptualization, remains. This is the meaning. The light imagined by the mind is Brahman. Since it is so, therefore (tasmāt).🔽🔽

analyzed: tāraka yoga svarūpam
translated: What is to be contemplated is of how many kinds? This is the essence of the higher Tāraka. The discrimination of internal things also depends on the mind and eye, like the discrimination of external things. Therefore it is said 'everywhere'. Because of seeing beings above that. Because of seeing the mark of the higher Tāraka, which shines between the eyebrows. By whom is this to be seen? By one united with the mind. Brahman alone is the mark of the higher Tāraka. This is to be contemplated. Since it is so, therefore. Even though the shining white light located between the eyebrows and so on is imagined by the mind, Brahman exists there also by being all-pervading. Therefore, by the firmness of the conviction that it is Brahman alone, when the mind dissolves into it, and the imagination requiring an imaginer is absent, Brahman alone, which is free from conceptualization, remains. This is the meaning. That light imagined by the mind is Brahman. Since it is so, therefore.
